abstract.text: Customize and receive events from asynchronous sources.

metadata.title: Receiving and Handling Events with Combine

inlineContent.text: The Combine framework provides a declarative approach for how your app processes
events. Rather than potentially implementing multiple delegate callbacks or completion
handler closures, you can create a single processing chain for a given event source.
Each part of the chain is a Combine operator that performs a distinct action on the
elements received from the previous step.
Consider an app that needs to filter a table or collection view based on the contents
of a text field. In AppKit, each keystroke in the text field produces a
that you can subscribe to with Combine. After receiving the notification, you can
use operators to change the content and timing of event delivery, and use the final
result to update your app’s user interface.

content.text: Connect a Publisher to a Subscriber

inlineContent.text: To receive the text field’s notifications with Combine, access the default instance

from, and returns a publisher that produces notification elements.
You use a
to receive elements from the publisher.
The subscriber defines an associated type,
to declare the type that it receives. The publisher also defines a type,
to declare what it produces. The publisher and subscriber both define a type,
to indicate the kind of error they produce or receive. To connect a subscriber to
a producer, the

Combine provides two built-in subscribers, which automatically match the output and
failure types of their attached publisher:
takes two closures. The first closure executes when it receives
, which is an enumeration that indicates whether the publisher finished normally or failed with an error. The second closure executes when it receives an element from the publisher.

For example, you can use the sink subscriber to log when the publisher completes,
and each time it receives an element:

content.text: Change the Output Type with Operators

inlineContent.text: The sink subscriber in the previous section performs all its work in the
closure. This could be burdensome if it needs to perform a lot of custom work with
received elements or maintain state between invocations. The advantage of Combine
comes from combining operators to customize event delivery.
For example,
isn’t a convenient type to receive in the callback if all you need is the text field’s
string value. Since a publisher’s output is essentially a sequence of elements over
time, Combine offers sequence-modifying operators like
, and
The behavior of these operators is similar to their equivalents in the Swift standard
library.
To change the output type of the publisher, you add a
operator whose closure returns a different type. In this case, you can get the notification’s
object as an

field’s

You can extend the
instance with an operator
that performs actions that you’d otherwise need to code manually. Here are three
ways you could use operators to improve this event-processing chain:
Rather than updating the view model with any string typed into the text field, you could use the
operator to ignore input under a certain length or to reject non-alphanumeric characters.
If the filtering operation is expensive — for example, if it’s querying a large database — you might want to wait for the user to stop typing. For this, the
operator lets you set a minimum period of time that must elapse before a publisher emits an event. The
class provides conveniences for specifying the time delay in seconds or milliseconds.
If the results update the UI, you can deliver callbacks to the main thread by calling the
method. By specifying the
instance provided by the
class as the first parameter, you tell Combine to call your subscriber on the main run loop.
The resulting publisher declaration follows:
A publisher continues to emit elements until it completes normally or fails. If you
no longer want to subscribe to the publisher, you can cancel the subscription. The
subscriber types created by
and

implementation forward the call to
the stored subscription.

abstract.text: Customize handling of asynchronous events by combining event-processing operators.
A protocol indicating that an activity or action supports cancellation.
Cancel the activity.
Declares that a type can transmit a sequence of values over time.
The kind of errors this publisher might publish.
The kind of values published by this publisher.
Assigns each element from a publisher to a property on an object.
Publishes elements only after a specified time interval elapses between events.
Republishes all elements that match a provided closure.
Transforms all elements from an upstream publisher into a new publisher up to a maximum number of publishers you specify.
Transforms all elements from the upstream publisher with a provided closure.
Specifies the scheduler on which to receive elements from the publisher.
Applies a closure that collects each element of a stream and publishes a final result upon completion.
Attaches a subscriber with closure-based behavior.
A protocol that defines when and how to execute a closure.
A protocol that declares a type that can receive input from a publisher.
The kind of values this subscriber receives.
A signal that a publisher doesn’t produce additional elements, either due to normal completion or an error.
A protocol representing the connection of a subscriber to a publisher.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an `NSString` object.
Text the user can select or edit to send an action message to a target when the user presses the Return key.
A container for information broadcast through a notification center to all registered observers.
A notification dispatch mechanism that enables the broadcast of information to registered observers.
Returns a publisher that emits events when broadcasting notifications.
The kind of values published by this publisher.
The programmatic interface to objects that manage input sources.
